page.title: 05Silage Making, N.Alcester
page.content: Silage is made on most farms in our area. This is how it is done on Coughton Cross Farm. The first thing the farmer does is to cut the grass with a special mower. After he has cut the grass he leaves it for 24 hours to mature. When the silage has been left, it is collected in a hopper. This is a trailer that collects grass as it is pulled along. The hopper is taken back to the farm where all the grass is gathered in a special area. When this is done they use a tractor to flatten it. They do this so that all the waste juice runs away. This juice is dangerous to fish so the farmer has a big tank for collecting it. The farmer puts plastic and tyres on top of the grass pile and leaves it to pickle for 8 weeks before using it as cattle fodder.
